ground_truth: The clock shows five past four. Pacing now, with his hands clasped together behind his head, a cigarette dangling between his lips, Brian looks alternately at his office floor, then at the clock. He looks up, awestruck, as silhouettes of fans leaping to their feet in celebration crowd the frosted windows. The clock ticks half-four. Brian sits with his head in his hands. He stands and once more peers up at the figures of the cheering Derby fans. He bows his head against the wall, then paces in the light streaming through the windows, his hands on his head. Brian puts on his jacket, straightens his tie and steps into the corridor. Outside his office door, he smooths both hands over his hair, then strides off down the gloomy, brick-walled passage. He stops in his tracks as he sees Jimmy and Peter turn the corner ahead. Jimmy strolls off, leaving Peter frowning at Brian. Peter's face softens into a grin. Beaming, Brian runs and embraces him. The team cheer in the dressing room. A Telex machine. Match footage. Brian in TV interview. Parkinson grins. Derby climb the table to the top. In interview again. Crowds welcome the Derby team bus back with the cup. Muhammad Ali on TV. Crowds flock down the mile to Wembley for the charity shield. Color TV footage from the time. Jimmy follows Brian into the Leeds dressing room. Brian takes a note from his blazer pocket. The team turn grudgingly. He grins and winks. Bremner shoots a dour glance at Giles. The teams come out. Bremner scratches his balls as he eyes Brown contemptuously, standing beside the team lined up for the national anthem. Don sings in the stands. On the pitch, Brian remains tight-lipped. Brian smirks wryly as he locks looks with Don, who looks away imperiously. Bremner salutes Don in the stands, who smiles back and touches his nose smugly. The Leeds team jig in a circle on the spot with their right arms raised to the fans. Liverpool on the edge of the Leeds area. Off the ball, Giles punches Keegan to the floor. Brian shuts his eyes. Commentators watch as Brian mutters furiously. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield. Brian's patted consolingly on the shoulder. At an FA tribunal. The row of gray-haired men in blazers rise. Bremner trudges out after the officials, leaving Brian sitting alone, brooding. Brian's on the phone in his hotel suite. Peter listens. Brian swigs booze. Peter's eyes rove in anguish as his brows knit in a frown. He hangs up. Brian is left hunched over on his hotel bed, head in hand. By the dressing rooms. Brian nods sagely, then leans close. Brian walks towards the players' tunnel.

Crowds flock down the avenue to Wembley for the charity shield. Color TV recording from the time. Jimmy follows Brian into the Leeds locker room. Brian takes a note from his jacket pocket. The squad turn reluctantly. He beams and winks. Bremner casts a stern glance at Giles. The squads emerge. Bremner scratches his groin as he eyes Brown disdainfully, standing beside the squad lined up for the national anthem. Don sings in the stands. On the field, Brian remains tight-lipped. Brian smirks slyly as he locks looks with Don, who gazes away haughtily. Bremner salutes Don in the stands, who smiles back and touches his nose arrogantly. The Leeds squad jig in a circle on the spot with their right arms elevated to the supporters. Liverpool on the verge of the Leeds area. Off the ball, Giles strikes Keegan to the ground. Brian closes his eyes. Commentators observe as Brian mutters furiously. Emlyn Hughes hoists the shield. Brian's patted consolingly on the shoulder. At an FA hearing. The row of gray-haired gentlemen in jackets rise. Bremner trudges out after the officials, leaving Brian sitting alone, musing. Brian's on the phone in his hotel suite. Peter listens. Now pacing, with his hands clasped together behind his head and a cigarette dangling between his lips, the office floor is looked at alternately by Brian, then at the clock. Awestruck, he looks up as the silhouettes of fans leaping to their feet in celebration crowd the frosted windows. Half-four is ticked by the clock. With his head in his hands, Brian sits. Both hands are smoothed over his hair outside his office door, then he strides off down the gloomy, brick-walled passage. In his tracks, he stops as Jimmy and Peter are seen turning the corner ahead. Jimmy strolls off, leaving Peter frowning at Brian. Into a grin, Peter's face softens. Beaming, he is embraced by Brian, who runs to him. The dressing room is cheered by the team. A Telex machine. Match footage. TV interviews Brian. Parkinson grins. The table is climbed by Derby to the top. In interview again. The Derby team bus is welcomed back by crowds with the cup. Muhammad Ali on TV. Down the mile to Wembley for the charity shield, crowds flock. Color TV footage from the time. Into the Leeds dressing room, Brian is followed by Jimmy. A note is taken by Brian from his blazer pocket. Grudgingly, the team turn. He grins and winks. A dour glance is shot by Bremner at Giles. The teams come out. As he eyes Brown contemptuously, Bremner scratches his balls, standing beside the team lined up for the national anthem. In the stands, Don sings. On the pitch, tight-lipped Brian remains. Wryly smirking, Brian locks looks with Don, who imperiously looks away. Don is saluted by Bremner in the stands, who smiles back and smugly touches his nose. In a circle on the spot with their right arms raised to the fans, the Leeds team jig. On the edge of the Leeds area, Liverpool are seen. Off the ball, Keegan is punched to the floor by Giles. Brian's eyes are shut. As Brian furiously mutters, commentators watch. The shield is lifted by Emlyn Hughes. Consolingly, Brian is patted on the shoulder. At an FA tribunal. The row of gray-haired men in blazers rise. Bremner trudges out after the officials, leaving Brian sitting alone, brooding. On the phone in his hotel suite, Brian's seen. Peter listens. Booze is swigged by Brian. In anguish, Peter's eyes rove as a frown is knitted by his brows. Up is hung by him. Hunched over on his hotel bed, Brian is left, head in hand. By the dressing rooms. Sagely, Brian nods, then close is leaned by him. Towards the players' tunnel, Brian walks.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: At five past four, Brian paces with a cigarette between his lips, glancing between the floor and the clock. Awestruck, he sees silhouettes of fans celebrating outside. At half-four, he sits with his head in his hands, then stands to watch the cheering Derby fans. He paces in the light, puts on his jacket, straightens his tie, and exits into the corridor. Smoothing his hair, he strides down the gloomy passage, stopping when he sees Jimmy and Peter. Jimmy leaves, and Peter grins at Brian, who runs to embrace him. The team cheers in the dressing room. A Telex machine, match footage, and Brian in a TV interview. Derby climbs to the top of the table. Crowds welcome the team bus with the cup. Muhammad Ali on TV. Crowds head to Wembley for the charity shield. Color TV footage. Jimmy follows Brian into the Leeds dressing room. Brian takes a note from his pocket, grinning and winking. Bremner glares at Giles. The teams emerge. Bremner eyes Brown contemptuously during the national anthem. Don sings in the stands. On the pitch, Brian remains tight-lipped, smirking wryly at Don. Bremner salutes Don, who touches his nose smugly. The Leeds team jigs in a circle. Liverpool nears the Leeds area. Off the ball, Giles punches Keegan. Brian shuts his eyes, muttering furiously. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield. Brian is consoled with a pat on the shoulder. At an FA tribunal, gray-haired officials rise. Bremner leaves, and Brian sits alone, brooding. In his hotel suite, Brian drinks while Peter listens, anguished. Brian is left hunched over on his bed. By the dressing rooms, Brian nods sagely, leans close, and walks toward the players' tunnel.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The clock on the wall indicates that it is five minutes past four. Brian, now pacing back and forth with a sense of restlessness, has his hands clasped together behind his head, while a cigarette dangles precariously between his lips. His gaze shifts alternately from the floor of his office to the clock, as if searching for answers. Suddenly, he looks up, awestruck, as the silhouettes of fans, who are leaping to their feet in joyous celebration, crowd the frosted windows. The clock ticks on, reaching half-past four. Brian sits down, his head cradled in his hands, overwhelmed by the moment. He stands up once more and peers up at the figures of the cheering Derby fans. With a sense of resignation, he bows his head against the wall, then resumes pacing in the light streaming through the windows, his hands resting on his head. Brian then puts on his jacket, straightens his tie with care, and steps out into the corridor. Just outside his office door, he smooths both hands over his hair, ensuring it is neat, before striding off down the gloomy, brick-walled passage. He comes to an abrupt stop as he sees Jimmy and Peter turning the corner ahead. Jimmy strolls off, leaving Peter standing there, frowning at Brian. However, Peter's face soon softens into a welcoming grin. Beaming with joy, Brian runs forward and embraces him warmly. Meanwhile, the team is cheering exuberantly in the dressing room. A Telex machine hums in the background. Match footage plays, showing Brian in a TV interview. Parkinson grins broadly. Derby climbs the table to reach the top. In another interview, Brian appears again. Crowds enthusiastically welcome the Derby team bus back, celebrating with the cup. Muhammad Ali appears on TV. Crowds flock down the mile to Wembley for the charity shield. Color TV footage from the time captures the excitement. Jimmy follows Brian into the Leeds dressing room. Brian takes a note from his blazer pocket, ready to share it. The team turns grudgingly to listen. He grins and winks, adding a touch of levity. Bremner shoots a dour glance at Giles. The teams come out onto the field. Bremner scratches his balls as he eyes Brown contemptuously, standing beside the team lined up for the national anthem. Don sings heartily in the stands. On the pitch, Brian remains tight-lipped, his expression unreadable. Brian smirks wryly as he locks eyes with Don, who looks away imperiously. Bremner salutes Don in the stands, who smiles back and touches his nose smugly. The Leeds team jigs in a circle on the spot with their right arms raised to the fans. Liverpool is on the edge of the Leeds area. Off the ball, Giles punches Keegan to the floor. Brian shuts his eyes, trying to block out the chaos. Commentators watch intently as Brian mutters furiously under his breath. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield triumphantly. Brian is patted consolingly on the shoulder. At an FA tribunal, the row of gray-haired men in blazers rise solemnly. Bremner trudges out after the officials, leaving Brian sitting alone, brooding over the situation. Brian is on the phone in his hotel suite, his voice tense. Peter listens intently. Brian swigs booze, trying to calm his nerves. Peter's eyes rove in anguish as his brows knit in a deep frown. He hangs up, leaving Brian hunched over on his hotel bed, his head in his hand, lost in thought. By the dressing rooms, Brian nods sagely, then leans in close, sharing a moment of understanding. Brian walks purposefully towards the players' tunnel, ready to face whatever comes next.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The clock mounted on the wall clearly indicates that the time is now five minutes beyond the hour of four. Brian, who is pacing back and forth relentlessly with a palpable sense of restlessness, has his hands clasped together behind his head in a gesture of anxiety, while a cigarette dangles precariously from the corner of his lips. His gaze shifts alternately and frequently from the worn floor of his office to the clock, as if seeking some sort of elusive answers. Abruptly, he looks up with a sense of awe as the silhouettes of exuberant fans, who are leaping to their feet in joyous celebration, crowd against the frosted windows, casting lively shadows. The clock continues its steady march, reaching the half-past four mark. Brian lowers himself into a seat, his head cradled heavily in his hands, overwhelmed by the magnitude of the moment. He stands again, drawn to the sight of the jubilant Derby fans, and peers intently at their cheering figures. With a sense of resignation, he bows his head against the wall, then resumes his restless pacing in the light streaming through the windows, his hands resting wearily on his head. Brian then methodically puts on his jacket and, with deliberate care, straightens his tie before stepping out into the corridor. Just outside the doorway of his office, he smooths both hands over his hair, ensuring it appears neat and tidy, before striding purposefully down the gloomy, brick-walled passage. He comes to a sudden halt as he spots Jimmy and Peter turning the corner ahead. Jimmy strolls off, leaving Peter standing there, frowning at Brian with a look of concern. However, Peter's expression soon softens into a welcoming grin that spreads across his face. Beaming with joy, Brian rushes forward and embraces him warmly, a gesture full of camaraderie. Meanwhile, in the dressing room, the team is cheering exuberantly, their voices echoing with excitement. A Telex machine hums rhythmically in the background, adding a quaint ambiance. Match footage is playing, showing Brian engaged in a TV interview, while Parkinson grins broadly, clearly delighted. Derby steadily climbs the table, reaching the pinnacle at the top. In another interview, Brian makes another appearance. Crowds enthusiastically welcome the Derby team bus upon its return, celebrating their triumph with the cup held high. Muhammad Ali appears on TV, a testament to the era. Crowds eagerly flock down the mile to Wembley, drawn by the allure of the charity shield. Vibrant color TV footage from the time captures the electric excitement of the occasion. Jimmy follows closely behind Brian as they enter the Leeds dressing room. Brian retrieves a note from the pocket of his blazer, ready to share it with those assembled. The team turns grudgingly to listen, a mix of reluctance and curiosity in their expressions. He grins and winks, infusing the moment with a touch of levity. Bremner casts a dour and sullen glance at Giles. The teams make their way onto the field, a spectacle of athletic pageantry. Bremner scratches his balls, his demeanor contemptuous as he eyes Brown, who stands beside the team lined up dutifully for the national anthem. Don sings heartily from his place in the stands, his voice carrying with enthusiasm. On the pitch, Brian remains tight-lipped, his expression guarded and unreadable. Brian smirks wryly as his eyes lock with Don's, who looks away imperiously. Bremner salutes Don in the stands, who responds with a smile and touches his nose smugly, a gesture of playful defiance. The Leeds team jigs spiritedly in a circle on the spot, their right arms raised triumphantly toward the cheering fans. Liverpool finds itself on the edge of the Leeds area. Off the ball, Giles throws a punch that sends Keegan to the floor. Brian shuts his eyes tightly, trying to block out the unfolding chaos. Commentators watch intently as Brian mutters furiously under his breath, frustration seeping through his words. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield triumphantly, a symbol of victory and celebration. Brian is patted consolingly on the shoulder, a gesture of support. At an FA tribunal, a row of gray-haired men in blazers rise solemnly, underscoring the gravity of the situation. Bremner trudges out after the officials, leaving Brian sitting alone, brooding thoughtfully over the situation. Brian, with a tense voice, speaks on the phone in his hotel suite. Peter listens intently, absorbing every word. Brian swigs a drink, attempting to calm his fraying nerves. Peter's anguished eyes rove over his features, his brows knitting into a deep frown. He hangs up, leaving Brian hunched over on his hotel bed, his head in his hand, lost in a sea of contemplation. By the dressing rooms, Brian nods sagely, then leans in close, sharing a moment of understanding with those around him. Brian walks purposefully towards the players' tunnel, his mind set and ready to face whatever challenges come next.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The clock displays five minutes past four, and Brian begins pacing back and forth, his hands clasped together behind his head, while a cigarette dangles precariously between his lips. His gaze shifts alternately from the office floor to the clock, as if willing time to move faster. Suddenly, he looks up, awestruck, as the silhouettes of fans, leaping to their feet in celebration, crowd the frosted windows, their excitement palpable even through the glass. The clock ticks on to half-past four, and Brian, feeling the weight of the moment, sits down with his head cradled in his hands. After a moment of contemplation, he stands again, drawn to the window, where he peers up at the figures of the cheering Derby fans, their energy infectious. He bows his head against the wall, feeling the cool surface against his forehead, then resumes pacing, this time in the light streaming through the windows, his hands resting on his head in a gesture of both frustration and anticipation. Resolute, Brian puts on his jacket, straightens his tie with a determined tug, and steps into the corridor. Outside his office door, he takes a moment to smooth both hands over his hair, ensuring every strand is in place, before striding off down the gloomy, brick-walled passage. His steps come to an abrupt halt as he spots Jimmy and Peter turning the corner ahead. Jimmy continues to stroll off, leaving Peter standing there, frowning at Brian. As their eyes meet, Peter's face softens into a grin, and Brian, beaming with relief and joy, runs forward to embrace him warmly. Meanwhile, the team erupts in cheers in the dressing room, their voices echoing with triumph. A Telex machine clatters in the background, and match footage flickers on a screen. Brian appears in a TV interview, his expression a mix of pride and satisfaction, while Parkinson grins beside him. Derby's climb up the table to the top is celebrated, and Brian finds himself in another interview, his confidence growing. Crowds gather to welcome the Derby team bus back, the cup held high in victory. On TV, Muhammad Ali's presence captivates viewers, while crowds flock down the mile to Wembley for the charity shield, the excitement captured in color TV footage from the time. Jimmy follows Brian into the Leeds dressing room, where Brian retrieves a note from his blazer pocket, unfolding it with care. The team turns grudgingly towards him, their expressions a mix of skepticism and curiosity. Brian grins and winks, his confidence unwavering, while Bremner shoots a dour glance at Giles, the tension palpable. As the teams come out, Bremner scratches his balls, eyeing Brown contemptuously as they stand beside the team lined up for the national anthem. In the stands, Don sings with fervor, his voice rising above the crowd. On the pitch, Brian remains tight-lipped, his focus unbroken. He smirks wryly as he locks eyes with Don, who looks away imperiously, refusing to acknowledge the silent challenge. Bremner salutes Don in the stands, who smiles back and touches his nose smugly, a gesture of mutual respect. The Leeds team jigs in a circle on the spot, their right arms raised in salute to the fans. Meanwhile, Liverpool presses on the edge of the Leeds area, the tension mounting. Off the ball, Giles punches Keegan to the floor, a moment of chaos that Brian witnesses with a heavy heart. He shuts his eyes, the weight of the situation pressing down on him. Commentators watch as Brian mutters furiously under his breath, his frustration evident. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield, a moment of triumph for some, while Brian is patted consolingly on the shoulder, a gesture of support in defeat. At an FA tribunal, a row of gray-haired men in blazers rise, their decision looming. Bremner trudges out after the officials, leaving Brian sitting alone, brooding over the outcome. Later, Brian is on the phone in his hotel suite, his voice a mix of determination and desperation, while Peter listens intently. Brian swigs booze, the liquid burning a path down his throat, as Peter's eyes rove in anguish, his brows knitting together in a frown. The call ends, and Peter hangs up, leaving Brian hunched over on his hotel bed, his head in his hand, the weight of the world on his shoulders. By the dressing rooms, Brian nods sagely, then leans close, his words meant only for those who need to hear them. With resolve, Brian walks towards the players' tunnel, each step a testament to his enduring spirit.

On the pitch, Brian remains tight-lipped, smirking wryly at Don, who looks away imperiously. Bremner salutes Don, who responds smugly. The Leeds team jigs in a circle, arms raised to the fans. Liverpool approaches the Leeds area, and off the ball, Giles punches Keegan. Brian shuts his eyes, muttering furiously as commentators watch. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield, and Brian is consoled with a pat on the shoulder. At an FA tribunal, gray-haired officials rise, and Bremner trudges out, leaving Brian brooding alone. In his hotel suite, Brian swigs booze while on the phone, as Peter listens with anguished eyes before hanging up, leaving Brian hunched over on his bed. test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The clock, an antique timepiece once belonging to his grandfather, shows five past four. Pacing now, with his hands clasped together behind his head, a cigarette dangling between his lips, Brian, a manager known for his tactical brilliance, looks alternately at his office floor, then at the clock. He looks up, awestruck, as silhouettes of fans leaping to their feet in celebration—likely Derby County supporters known for their passionate following—crowd the frosted windows. The clock ticks half-four. Brian sits with his head in his hands, the pressure of the match outcome weighing on him. He stands and once more peers up at the figures of the cheering Derby fans, who seem to have witnessed another thrilling goal. He bows his head against the wall, then paces in the light streaming through the windows, his hands on his head filled with strategic thoughts. Brian puts on his jacket, a smart blazer that matches his preferred managerial style, straightens his tie and steps into the corridor. Outside his office door, he smooths both hands over his hair, then strides off down the gloomy, brick-walled passage, reminiscent of the historic football stadium halls. He stops in his tracks as he sees Jimmy and Peter, both members of his trusted coaching staff, turn the corner ahead. Jimmy strolls off, leaving Peter frowning at Brian, likely concerned about the team's performance. Peter's face softens into a grin, a gesture of camaraderie and shared relief. Beaming, Brian runs and embraces him, celebrating their shared victory. The team cheer in the dressing room, their voices echoing through the stadium. A Telex machine—still used at this time to send scores and news—clatters nearby. Match footage plays, highlighting their recent success. Brian in TV interview, speaking confidently about the team's prospects. Parkinson, the famous television host, grins, acknowledging Brian's rising fame. Derby climb the table to the top, a remarkable achievement for the club. In interview again, Brian's charisma shines through. Crowds welcome the Derby team bus back with the cup, a triumphant return for the fans. Muhammad Ali on TV, a global icon of the era, inspires many with his skill and personality. Crowds flock down the mile to Wembley for the charity shield, a prestigious event in English football. Color TV footage from the time, capturing the vibrancy of the moment. Jimmy follows Brian into the Leeds dressing room, a tense environment due to their rivalry. Brian takes a note from his blazer pocket, perhaps a tactic or motivational word. The team turn grudgingly, reflecting on their last match. He grins and winks, confidence brimming. Bremner, the fierce Leeds captain, shoots a dour glance at Giles, his loyal teammate. The teams come out, the air thick with anticipation. Bremner scratches his balls as he eyes Brown contemptuously, a psychological tactic to assert dominance, standing beside the team lined up for the national anthem. Don, a respected figure in the stands, sings along with fervor. On the pitch, Brian remains tight-lipped, a mask of concentration. Brian smirks wryly as he locks looks with Don, who looks away imperiously, acknowledging the mind games at play. Bremner salutes Don in the stands, who smiles back and touches his nose smugly, an inside gesture known to few. The Leeds team jig in a circle on the spot with their right arms raised to the fans, a unique celebration. Liverpool, their formidable opponents, on the edge of the Leeds area. Off the ball, Giles punches Keegan to the floor, an infamous act that becomes a talking point. Brian shuts his eyes, frustration etched on his face. Commentators watch as Brian mutters furiously, noting his animated displeasure. Emlyn Hughes, the Liverpool captain, lifts the shield, a defining moment in the game. Brian's patted consolingly on the shoulder, a gesture of support from his staff. At an FA tribunal, a place of judgment and consequence for the game. The row of gray-haired men in blazers rise, authoritative figures in football governance. Bremner trudges out after the officials, leaving Brian sitting alone, brooding over the loss and decisions ahead. Brian's on the phone in his hotel suite, a room lavishly decked with team memorabilia. Peter listens, his concern for Brian palpable. Brian swigs booze, a moment of personal turmoil. Peter's eyes rove in anguish as his brows knit in a frown, sharing in Brian's burden. He hangs up, the weight of the call lingering. Brian is left hunched over on his hotel bed, head in hand, contemplating the next steps for his career. By the dressing rooms, a place filled with echoes of past matches. Brian nods sagely, then leans close, offering strategic whispers to a key player. Brian walks towards the players' tunnel, ready to face whatever comes next in this journey.

Brian looks alternately at his office floor then at the clock. He looks up awestruck as silhouettes of fans leaping to their feet in celebration. crowd the frosted windows. The clock ticks halffour. The team turn grudgingly. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. He grins and winks. Bremner shoots a dour glance at Giles. The teams come out. Bremner scratches his balls as he eyes Brown contemptuously standing beside the team lined up for the national anthem. Don sings in the stands. On the pitch. Brian remains tightlipped. Brian smirks wryly as he locks looks with Don who looks away imperiously. Bremner salutes Don in the stands who smiles back and touches his nose smugly. The Leeds team jig in a circle on the spot with their right arms raised to the fans. Liverpool on the edge of the Leeds area. Off the ball. Giles punches Keegan to the floor. Brian shuts his eyes. Commentators watch as Brian mutters furiously. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield. Brian's patted consolingly on the shoulder. At an FA tribunal. The row of grayhaired men in blazers rise. Bremner trudges out after the officials leaving Brian sitting alone brooding. Brian's on the phone in his hotel suite. Peter listens. Brian swigs booze. Peter's eyes rove in anguish as his brows knit in a frown. He hangs up. Brian is left hunched over on his hotel bed. head in hand. By the dressing rooms. Brian nods sagely then leans close. Brian walks towards the players' tunnel.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: The clock shows five past four. Pacing now with his hands clasped together behind his head a cigarette dangling between his lips. Brian looks alternately at his office floor then at the clock. He looks up awestruck as silhouettes of fans leaping to their feet in celebration. crowd the frosted windows. The clock ticks halffour. Brian sits with his head in his hands. He stands and once more peers up at the figures of the cheering Derby fans. He bows his head against the wall then paces in the light streaming through the windows his hands on his head. Brian puts on his jacket straightens his tie and steps into the corridor. Outside his office door he smooths both hands over his hair then strides off down the gloomy brickwalled passage. He stops in his tracks as he sees Jimmy and Peter turn the corner ahead. Jimmy strolls off leaving Peter frowning at Brian. Peter's face softens into a grin. Beaming. Brian runs and embraces him. The team cheer in the dressing room. A Telex machine. Match footage. Brian in TV interview. Parkinson grins. Derby climb the table to the top. In interview again. Crowds welcome the Derby team bus back with the cup. Muhammad Ali on TV. Crowds flock down the mile to Wembley for the charity shield. Color TV footage from the time. Jimmy follows Brian into the Leeds dressing room. Brian takes a note from his blazer pocket. The team turn grudgingly. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The lamp shows four past midnight. Crawling now, with her feet kicking together beneath her chair, a pencil dangling between her fingers, Sarah glances alternately at her bedroom ceiling, then at the lamp. She glances sideways, bewildered, as shadows of birds flying from their nests in confusion cover the frosted mirrors. The lamp strokes half-midnight. Sarah lies with her hat in her arms. She leaps and once more gazes sideways at the outlines of the clapping cat herd. She nods her hat against the bookshelf, then crawls in the shadow streaming through the mirrors, her feet on her hat. Sarah puts on her scarf, loosens her shoelaces and shuffles into the hallway. Inside her bedroom curtain, she straightens both legs over her knees, then waddles off down the bright, wallpapered corridor. She skips in her way as she hears Oliver and Nicole swing the door outside. Oliver rides off, leaving Nicole cursing at Sarah. Nicole's hand stiffens into a wave. Nodding, Sarah jumps and tickles her. The band sings in the dining hall. A fax machine. Concert footage. Sarah in radio interview. Griffith cackles. Norwich slide the river to the base. In chat again. Scientists surprise the Norwich bicycle van off with the rose. Neil Armstrong on radio. Scientists glide down the hill to Glastonbury for the music festival. Black-and-white film footage from the story. Oliver chases Sarah into the Bristol classroom. Sarah pulls a wallet from her jacket pouch. The band twirl enthusiastically. She shrugs and yawns. Sanders points a bright look at Mason. The bands march in. Sanders flicks his fingers as he feels McKay softly, walking beside the band scattered for the closing prayer. Tom groans in the crowd. In the gym, Sarah stays open-mouthed. Sarah laughs openly as she locks winks with Tom, who winks away joylessly. Sanders praises Tom in the crowd, who leans down and scratches his ears roughly. The Bristol band hop in a triangle on the floor with their left legs lowered to the scientists. Chelsea within the center of the Bristol garden. Above the hill, Mason pushes Jenkins to the roof. Sarah opens her mouth. Officers listen as Sarah whispers softly. Stan Smith lowers the boot. Sarah’s touched lightly on the ankle. On a UN meeting. The row of dark-haired women in dresses sit. Sanders sprints out before the architects, leaving Sarah standing quietly, thinking. Sarah's on the letter in her villa garage. Nicole talks. Sarah sips water. Nicole's nose wanders in joy as her lips stretch in joy. She puts down. Sarah is left stretched out on her villa couch, leg in foot. Outside the cupboards. Sarah winks shyly, then sits far. Sarah leans away from the gardeners’ cave.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Brian anxiously paces his office, checking the clock and observing celebrating silhouettes of Derby fans through frosted windows. As the clock ticks, Brian straightens his tie, leaves his office, and encounters Peter, who smiles and embraces him. Derby celebrates their victory, reaching the top of the table and returning with the cup. At Wembley for the charity shield match, Brian enters the Leeds dressing room, facing a grudging team. On the pitch, Brian shares tense glances with Don. The Leeds team performs for their fans, while Liverpool attacks. Giles punches Keegan, and Brian closes his eyes in frustration. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield, and Brian is consoled. Post-match, Brian broods alone at an FA tribunal, then drinks in his hotel room, distressed after a call with Peter. Finally, Brian approaches the players' tunnel, determined.
